key_insight: A network-aware self-supervised learning pipeline can learn label-free, biologically meaningful representations of neuronal activity dynamics, enabling high-content phenotypic screening to identify genetic modifiers across diverse neural interventions.
problem_solved: Scales up detection of subtle, network-level changes in neuronal activity without manual labels or handcrafted features, overcoming limits of conventional single-cell or supervised screening methods.
method: Train self-supervised models that incorporate network structure and temporal dynamics from neuronal activity recordings as pretext tasks.
Produce low-dimensional embeddings that capture network-level phenotypes and similarity between perturbations.
Use embeddings for high-content screening: cluster, compare, and prioritize genetic modifiers across multiple interventions and datasets.
impact: Offers a general, label-free framework for learning interpretable representations of dynamical biological networks, accelerating scalable perturbation screens and enabling transfer of ML tools to other networked time-series applications.
visual_elements: Pipeline schematic: raw neuronal activity (raster/voltage traces) → network-aware SSL model → embedding space → phenotypic hits
Side-by-side time-series examples mapped to embedding clusters to show phenotypic separation
Heatmap or volcano-style plot of perturbation effects across genes/interventions
Schematic plate/well map or scalability icon to highlight high-throughput screening capability
paper_title: Network-aware self-supervised learning enables high-content phenotypic screening for genetic modifiers of neuronal activity dynamics
paper_authors: Parker Grosjean, Kaivalya Shevade, Cuong Nguyen, Sarah Ancheta, Karl Mader
